content.text: Calculate the value of bond D shown in the following table, all of which pay interest semiannually. <image 1>

To calculate the value of bond D, we need to use the bond valuation formula. The formula is:

\[ \text{Bond Value} = \left( \frac{\text{Coupon Payment}}{\text{Required Rate of Return}} \right) \times \left( 1 - \frac{1}{(1 + \text{Required Rate of Return})^{\text{Number of Periods}}} \right) + \frac{\text{Par Value}}{(1 + \text{Required Rate of Return})^{\text{Number of Periods}}} \]

Given:
- Par Value = $1,000
- Coupon Rate = 14%
- Required Rate of Return = 10%
- Years to Maturity = 10
- Payments per Year = 2 ( (since it pays interest semiannually)

First, calculate the semiannual coupon payment:
\[ \text{Semiannual Coupon Payment} = \frac{\text{Par Value} \times \text{Coupon Rate}}{2} = \frac{1,000 \times 0.14}{2} = 70 \]

Next, calculate the semiannual required rate of return:
\[ \text{Semiannual Required Rate of Return} = \frac{\text{Required Rate of Return}}{2} = \frac{0.10}{2} = 0.05 \]

Now, calculate the number of periods:
\[ \text{Number of Periods} = \text{Years to Maturity} \times \text{Payments per Year} = 10 \times 2 = 20 \]

Finally, plug these values into the bond valuation formula:
\[ \text{Bond Value} = \left( \frac{70}{0.05} \right) \times \left( 1 - \frac{1}{(1 + 0.05)^{20}} \right) + \frac{1,000}{(1 + 0.05)^{20}} \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 1,400 \times \left( 1 - \frac{1}{(1.05)^{20}} \right) + \frac{1,000}{(1.05)^{20}} \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 1,400 \times \left( 1 - \frac{1}{2.6533} \right) + \frac{1,000}{2.6533} \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 1,400 \times \left( 1 - 0.3769 \right) + 377.67 \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 1,400 \times 0.6231 + 377.67 \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 872.64 + 377.67 \]

\[ \text{Bond Value} = 1,250.31 \]

So, the value of bond D is approximately $1,250.31.
